channel.title: How does programming work?
channel.description: i know how to code i self taught myself and i understand most of it but i sense im missing something i feel like what i do is more code manipulation instead of programming and by that i mean i can take a look at a source code i can understand what the program is attempting to do i can manipulate code to make it preform the way i want and i can fix code that i myself write but the one thing i haven't been able to teach myself is where all code originates from im not capable of writing new code from scratch because of this and as a result my skills are severely limited to code manipulation can someone please explain what it is im missing

item.title: How does programming work?
item.dc:creator: @tigerclan tigerclan
item.description:
@tigerclan wrote:

Roar337:

i would like to read all the classes and methods in the api where can i find them? also programs are built relying on the creators creativity i imagine this library of classes will be huge any tips for finding the specific things i may be looking for at any given time?

http://docs.oracle.com/javase/7/docs/api/

read these as well if you actually want to learn java: http://docs.oracle.com/javase/tutorial/

Read full topic

item.title: How does programming work?
item.dc:creator: @tigerclan tigerclan
item.description:
@tigerclan wrote:

[quote=“Roar337, post:11, topic:520743”]yea that guy was right i downloaded project insanity and i was able to make sense of the code thats how i originally learned programming anyways i took a look at a object oriented programming video and he explained everything i already knew the only thing he didn’t explain is what i wanted to know… i understood everything except System.out.println i know what that does it prints a string to the console but what i dont know is where that came from all of the code in that program was made by that guy except System.out.println and Math.random but these things seem to work in all programs and for this specific program its the original code that everything else was built from i know they are coming from some class somewhere but where? here is the video i watched also i know alot about programming binary its origins and all of that thats not what im asking…

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=3WtxkG5gSjU[/quote]

System.out and Math are part of the Java API(the library of classes that comes with Java)

Read full topic

item.title: How does programming work?
item.dc:creator: @Fire_capez Fire capez
item.description:
@Fire_capez wrote:

[quote=“Bowser jr, post:9, topic:520743”]FireCapez: Programming is much older than computers. Using first in the textile industry. Binary isn’t a language, but a base 2 representation of numbers/letters.

You are making binary programming much harder than it is. The first machines wasn’t a complex x86 processor.[/quote]

I know that binary is a base 2 number system it dates to the 17th century; binary is the foundation of digital systems, obviously various machines predate it, good examples are the abacus the analytic engine and the jacquard loom but these were not digital. (sorry about the commas lol)

Binary is the basis of digital computing thus, we begin there.

Read full topic

item.title: How does programming work?
item.dc:creator: @xxxtilllyxxx xxxtilllyxxx
item.description:
@xxxtilllyxxx wrote:

I think OT is talking about something along the lines of a framework? I.e, he downloads a PI, follows some tutorials and finds it easy. But when it comes to writing something on his own, he doesn’t understand where to start. Well, OOP is where, also what Wintercanon said, logic. That’s all programming is. 90% though, 10% writing.

Read full topic

item.title: How does programming work?
item.dc:creator: @Fire_capez Fire capez
item.description:
@Fire_capez wrote:

if you’re talking about how modern day programming languages came to be:

Binary - Assembly interpreter - Assembly - C compiler - C - you get the picture
(Binary stems from electrical circuits only representing two states, on and off: 0 and 1, if I go further it will end up as which came first the chicken or the egg question)

Read full topic

item.title: How does programming work?
item.dc:creator: @Wintercanon Wintercanon
item.description:
@Wintercanon wrote:

Programming is just logic. You combine logic to make more logic and just constantly build upon that. You need to understand the fundamentals of programming, which can generally be applied to any language; you understand the concept of variables, functions and memory. You then learn from example by looking at others’ code and try apply that to other problems. Mainly it’s just practice, you need to create situations that feel impossible to solve and then solve them. Do this repeatedly and remember you need to write thousands of lines of terrible code to learn to write efficient code.

Read full topic

item.title: How does programming work?
item.dc:creator: @tigerclan tigerclan
item.description:
@tigerclan wrote:

[quote=“Roar337, post:4, topic:520743”][quote author=tigerclan link=topic=639255.msg4308594#msg4308594 date=1370350323]
Most beginner tutorials go over this, in whichever language you decide to use. In the beginning everyone had to write programs in binary(011010100). Over time they created languages that are just compiled into binary code, making it easier for humans to set commands for computers to execute. <- Super simple answer

http://www.codeconquest.com/what-is-coding/how-does-coding-work/
[/quote]

yes im fairly familiar with binary however you seem to be telling me to code in binary which is impossible or at least highly inefficient the language im most familiar with is java im not really asking for origins like in the beginning stuff im asking as a person makes a program from scratch what point do they start at maybe libraries or api’s?[/quote]

I’m not telling you to write in binary. I’m just telling you that languages are interpreted and then computed in binary. Therefor you can code in plain english(sort of lol), and the compiler and computer do all the heavy work. As for libraries, it’s really hard to tell you what libraries to use. Obviously the main java api is going to be used in literally almost all of your applications, so I guess start there. But honestly, you just learn to write a basic program. If you need to write something more complex, like, a server or something, then you learn libraries you need to efficiently write that(like java.io and java.nio). If you can give a more specific question it will be easier for us to answer

Read full topic
